title: Characterization and Customization of Individual EDS Detectors to Improve X-ray Microanalysis of Light Elements
content: In energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) detectors, incoming X-rays ionize Si atoms of the semiconductor sensor to produce electron-hole pairs and the electrons then drift towards the anode. The depth at which electron-hole pairs are created inside the sensor depends on the photoelectric absorption of incoming X-rays in Si and scattering of resulting photoelectrons [1, 2]. As shown in Figure 1, X-rays with an energy less than 1 keV or slightly above the Si K absorption edge are completely absorbed within the first micrometers, whereas high-energy X-rays are absorbed at greater depth inside the sensor. Absorption near the surface means that electron-hole pairs may get trapped or recombined, resulting in a loss of charge and therefore counts appearing in the spectrum at lower energies than the true energy of the incoming X-rays. This phenomenon is known as incomplete charge collection (ICC). It is observed as a tail on the low energy side of X-ray peaks, an increase in spectral resolution, and a shift of the centroid [1-4]. Figure 2 compares two spectra acquired from detectors with significant and negligible ICC. Especially for light elements, as their only characteristic X-ray lines are below 1 keV, ICC can adversely impact element identification (peaks don’t appear at the right energies and tailing may complicate the detection of minor elements [2, 3]), deconvolution (width and shape of peaks don’t match theory [2]) and quantification (counts in tail need to be included in peak profiles to get the correct net intensity [3, 5]).
